Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery plate with broad offset horizontal rim; white slip; on top of rim, rays; on outside of floor dots between pairs of lines; in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of lion to right (rump, body and mane remaining; added red on hind leg, underbelly and mane); incised pendant and full rosettes with red as filling ornament; on edge of rim, diagonal strokes; exterior: black band on rim; billet pattern between narrow bands; below, solid rays.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group A of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The decoration on the vases from this group is the most elaborate. The rosette has a standard cogwheel shape, the figures are carefully drawn and details are expertly incised.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 147, p. 319, no. 1408, pl. 180) (Incorrectly labelled as 'missing')
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 34, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2151) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
